The Great Plague of London lasted from 1665 to 1666 and was the last major epidemic of the bubonic plague in England. The unsanitary and overcrowded City of London had suffered from numerous outbreaks of the plague over the centuries, but the Great Plague of 1665-1666 is remembered as the most significant. The plague flared up dramatically in June 1665, with a significant increase in fatalities. The outbreak led to around 60,000 deaths, which was one fifth of the population at the time. The King and his court left London to avoid the plague, and the City began using Bunhill Fields as a burial ground for the victims.
